snippet: The California Supreme Court has limited the reach of the state's ''three strikes'' sentencing law, ruling that a juvenile burglary conviction cannot be counted as a strike.    By a unanimous vote on Thursday, the court threw out an eight-year pri...
lead_paragraph: The California Supreme Court has limited the reach of the state's ''three strikes'' sentencing law, ruling that a juvenile burglary conviction cannot be counted as a strike. By a unanimous vote on Thursday, the court threw out an eight-year prison term for Edwin Garcia of San Diego, whose sentence was doubled under the three-strikes law because he had been convicted in juvenile court of burglarizing a home.
abstract: California Supreme Court rules that a juvenile burglary conviction cannot be counted as a strike under state's 'three strikes' sentencing law (S)

headline.main: National News Briefs; California Court Limits Sentencing Law
